articles.headline: Americans Celebrate and Mourn Abortion Decision as New Fights Loom
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court sent the issue of abortion back to the states in an even more polarized era than when Roe v. Wade was introduced.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court sent the issue of abortion back to the states in an even more polarized era than when Roe v. Wade was introduced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within minutes of the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade on Friday, the attorney general in Missouri issued an opinion banning abortion in his state. Abortion clinics in several cities, including Montgomery, Ala., and Sioux Falls, S.D., shut down. But others in Illinois and Ohio kept seeing patients.

articles.headline: ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Becomes a New Way to Pay for Guns
articles.snippet: Credova, a little-known fintech company, is leading the way in offering installment plans to buyers of guns and hunting supplies.
articles.abstract: Credova, a little-known fintech company, is leading the way in offering installment plans to buyers of guns and hunting supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, as American consumers were being wooed with “buy now, pay later” loans that let them pay for online purchases — from makeup to Peloton bikes — in small increments, one start-up had an idea: Why not adapt the model to sell outdoor recreation gear, including guns?

articles.headline: Companies Are More Vocal Than Ever on Social Issues. Not on Abortion.
articles.snippet: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
articles.abstract: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies had more than a month to formulate a response to the end of federal abortion rights in the United States, if they didn’t weigh in immediately after a draft opinion was leaked in May.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Lora Kelley

articles.headline: ‘It’s Become Real’: Abortion Decision Roils Midterms, Sending Fight to States
articles.snippet: Democrats hope the fall of Roe v. Wade will jolt abortion rights supporters into action in midterm elections. But is it enough to turn voters’ attention away from inflation?
articles.abstract: Democrats hope the fall of Roe v. Wade will jolt abortion rights supporters into action in midterm elections. But is it enough to turn voters’ attention away from inflation?
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday catapulted the explosive battle over abortion rights into the center of several marquee midterm races, turning the fight over key governor’s contests and coveted Senate seats into heated debates about personal freedom and public health.

articles.headline: Abortion Ruling Poses New Questions About How Far Supreme Court Will Go
articles.snippet: The decision overruling Roe v. Wade exposed internal divisions among conservative justices about reconsidering other rights.
articles.abstract: The decision overruling Roe v. Wade exposed internal divisions among conservative justices about reconsidering other rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to end the constitutional right to abortion concluded one battle for now but immediately posed another far-reaching question: whether the judicial ground under rights in other personal matters, including contraception and same-sex marriage, is now also shaky.

articles.headline: Kavanaugh Gave Private Assurances. Collins Says He ‘Misled’ Her.
articles.snippet: “I am a don’t-rock-the-boat kind of judge,” the justice told the senator in a discussion on Roe, according to notes from a meeting before his confirmation.
articles.abstract: “I am a don’t-rock-the-boat kind of judge,” the justice told the senator in a discussion on Roe, according to notes from a meeting before his confirmation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During a two-hour meeting in her Senate office with the Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh on Aug. 21, 2018, Senator Susan Collins of Maine pressed him hard on why she should trust him not to overturn Roe v. Wade if she backed his confirmation.

articles.headline: How Elon Musk Helped Lift the Ceiling on C.E.O. Pay
articles.snippet: The gap with workers widened even further as public companies granted top executives rich pay packages partly inspired by Tesla.
articles.abstract: The gap with workers widened even further as public companies granted top executives rich pay packages partly inspired by Tesla.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tesla awarded Elon Musk a multibillion-dollar pay package in 2018, the landmark deal helped to vastly increase the potential compensation of the chief executives at many of America’s biggest public companies.

articles.headline: Commando Network Coordinates Flow of Weapons in Ukraine, Officials Say
articles.snippet: A secretive operation involving U.S. Special Operations forces hints at the scale of the effort to assist Ukraine’s still outgunned military.
articles.abstract: A secretive operation involving U.S. Special Operations forces hints at the scale of the effort to assist Ukraine’s still outgunned military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Russian troops press ahead with a grinding campaign to seize eastern Ukraine, the nation’s ability to resist the onslaught depends more than ever on help from the United States and its allies — including a stealthy network of commandos and spies rushing to provide weapons, intelligence and training, according to U.S. and European officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: How the House Jan. 6 Panel Has Redefined the Congressional Hearing
articles.snippet: No bloviating speeches or partisan rancor. Lots of video and a tight script. The story of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold on to power is being unspooled in a way totally new to Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: No bloviating speeches or partisan rancor. Lots of video and a tight script. The story of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold on to power is being unspooled in a way totally new to Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: The typical congressional hearing features a pileup of long-winded statements — what some might consider bloviating. There are harsh partisan exchanges that can obscure the substance at hand. Visual presentations tend to involve an easel. The television audience is largely on C-SPAN.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Americans Face New Abortion Landscape in Wake of Roe Decision
articles.snippet: Around the country, a patchwork of laws was taking hold amid protest and celebration.
articles.abstract: Around the country, a patchwork of laws was taking hold amid protest and celebration.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new and rapidly shifting reality took hold across America on Saturday as abortion, a basic legal right for nearly a half century, was outlawed in some states, and the initial bursts of elation and shock from the overturning of Roe v. Wade gave way to action.

articles.headline: How Did Roe Fall? Before a Decisive Ruling, a Powerful Red Wave.
articles.snippet: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
articles.abstract: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.

articles.headline: ‘An Invisible Cage’: How China Is Policing the Future
articles.snippet: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
articles.abstract: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The more than 1.4 billion people living in China are constantly watched. They are recorded by police cameras that are everywhere, on street corners and subway ceilings, in hotel lobbies and apartment buildings. Their phones are tracked, their purchases are monitored, and their online chats are censored.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao and John Liu

articles.headline: Schools Are Spending Billions on High-Tech Defense for Mass Shootings
articles.snippet: The market for weapon detectors and crisis alert badges in schools is booming. But there are questions about whether the new technology is effective.
articles.abstract: The market for weapon detectors and crisis alert badges in schools is booming. But there are questions about whether the new technology is effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reid Bauer was finishing lunch period last year at his middle school in the Atlanta area when an alarm began blaring through the halls, warning of an emergency. Reid, then in sixth grade, had never heard the school’s “code red” alert before.

articles.headline: The Ruling Was Just the Beginning: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
articles.snippet: Lawyers, politicians and advocacy groups responded to Friday’s Supreme Court ruling with fresh plans for the fight over abortion rights.
articles.abstract: Lawyers, politicians and advocacy groups responded to Friday’s Supreme Court ruling with fresh plans for the fight over abortion rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: Russian Strike on Kyiv Looms Over G7 Summit
articles.snippet: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
articles.abstract: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
articles.lead_paragraph: TELFS, Austria — Leaders of the Group of 7 nations said Sunday they would stop buying gold from Moscow and discussed a new American proposal to undercut its oil revenues, even as Russian forces rained missiles on Kyiv for the first time in weeks. The dueling escalation underscored how the war in Ukraine has consumed global politics and the world economy.

articles.headline: The Final Days of Mississippi’s Last Abortion Clinic
articles.snippet: The Jackson Women’s Health Organization was at the center of the case that overturned Roe v. Wade. Already, supporters are planning new ways to help women in one of the poorest spots in the nation get access to abortions.
articles.abstract: The Jackson Women’s Health Organization was at the center of the case that overturned Roe v. Wade. Already, supporters are planning new ways to help women in one of the poorest spots in the nation get access to abortions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: The Strange Tale of Tina Peters
articles.snippet: The county clerk has been consumed by election conspiracy theories, lionized by a movement and indicted in a bizarre scheme. Will Republicans nominate her to run elections in Colorado?
articles.abstract: The county clerk has been consumed by election conspiracy theories, lionized by a movement and indicted in a bizarre scheme. Will Republicans nominate her to run elections in Colorado?
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in Colorado.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Russia Misses Bond Deadline, Signaling Its First Default on Foreign Debt Since 1918
articles.snippet: Economic sanctions that blocked bond payments have strengthened efforts to seal off Moscow from global markets.
articles.abstract: Economic sanctions that blocked bond payments have strengthened efforts to seal off Moscow from global markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia missed a deadline for making bond payments on Sunday, a move signaling its first default on international debt in more than a century, after Western sanctions thwarted the government’s efforts to pay foreign investors. The lapse adds to efforts to seal Moscow off from global capital markets for years.

articles.headline: The Former Electrical Engineer Leading Disney’s Streaming Strategy
articles.snippet: Kareem Daniel has become one of the entertainment industry’s most powerful executives, exposing him to Hollywood’s slings and arrows.
articles.abstract: Kareem Daniel has become one of the entertainment industry’s most powerful executives, exposing him to Hollywood’s slings and arrows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kareem Daniel was on crutches in the spring of 2002. He had broken his right ankle playing basketball. But Mr. Daniel had no time to convalesce: A self-imposed clock was ticking on his attempt to change careers — to abandon safe-and-steady electrical engineering, a field that his parents had pushed, for the wild-and-woolly movie business, which was his dream.

articles.headline: Boeing 737 Max Flies Again, but Crash Victims’ Kin Say Risks Remain
articles.snippet: Families are working with industry insiders to press for new safety precautions and a review of production practices for the aircraft.
articles.abstract: Families are working with industry insiders to press for new safety precautions and a review of production practices for the aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been 18 months since Boeing’s 737 Max was allowed to start flying passengers again, but some of the families that lost loved ones in a pair of fatal crashes of the plane say they are still worried about its safety.

articles.headline: What the ban on Russia’s gold imports means for its increasingly isolated economy.
articles.snippet: The move by the United States, Britain and others builds on steps to cut off Russia from the international financial system.
articles.abstract: The move by the United States, Britain and others builds on steps to cut off Russia from the international financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision over the weekend to ban the purchase of newly mined and refined gold from Russia is the latest effort by the United States, Britain and their allies to notch up the wave of sanctions concentrated on Russia in response to its four-month-old invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Sides With Coach Over Prayers at the 50-Yard Line
articles.snippet: Joseph Kennedy, a former high school football coach in Bremerton, Wash., had a constitutional right to pray on the field after his team’s games, the justices ruled.
articles.abstract: Joseph Kennedy, a former high school football coach in Bremerton, Wash., had a constitutional right to pray on the field after his team’s games, the justices ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a high school football coach had a constitutional right to pray at the 50-yard line after his team’s games, the latest step by the court in expanding the place of religion in public life.

articles.headline: Abortion Rights Groups Take Up the Fight in the States
articles.snippet: Abortion rights advocates filed lawsuits to halt or delay bans on abortion in some states, with judges in Louisiana and Utah temporarily blocking new laws.
articles.abstract: Abortion rights advocates filed lawsuits to halt or delay bans on abortion in some states, with judges in Louisiana and Utah temporarily blocking new laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The battle over abortion shifted to the states on Monday as a weekend of furious protest and prayerful thanksgiving in the wake of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade reversal gave way to a coast-to-coast wave of lawsuits, legislation and pitched political fights.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Mitch Smith
